metadata.title: Text mining: What are people doing at home during the Coronavirus quarantine? | by fylim | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Text mining: What are people doing at home during the Coronavirus quarantine?
metadata.description: As more countries declare a nationwide shutdown, most of the people are asked to stay at home and quarantined. I wanted to know how people are spending their time and how they are feeling during this…

all_paragraphs: As more countries declare a nationwide shutdown, most of the people are asked to stay at home and quarantined. I wanted to know how people are spending their time and how they are feeling during this “closedown ” period, so I analyzed some tweets in this article, hoping that the data will give me some insights.
For the dataset, I extracted 20,000 tweets with “#quarantine” and “#stayhome” hashtags from Twitter using the twitteR library.
After importing the data into R, we need to pre-process and tokenize the tweets into words (tokens) for analysis
After the dataset is tokenized and pre-processed, we need to remove stop words such as “for,” “the,” “an,” etc. that are not useful for analysis.
We can also do a quick check to see how many stop words have been removed from the dataset by using the codes below:
And the result would look like this:
At this point, our dataset should be clean and ready to be analyzed!
A common method of doing text mining is to look at word frequencies. First, let’s look at some most common words in our tweets.
Clearly, the quarantine is related to the Coronavirus / COVID-19 situation, and people are staying home to avoid being exposed to the virus.
After obtaining the word frequencies, we can use the “NRC” lexicon to assign a label (positive or negative) to each word. Then, we can create a word cloud tagged to the labels.

From the word cloud, we know that most people are stressed and bored during this isolation period. But on the bright side, we also learn that people are sending out kind messages, telling others to stay safe and healthy.
Sentiment analysis helps us identify expressed text and opinions from text data. It helps us understand people’s attitudes and feelings towards a particular topic.
While people fear for the Coronavirus, most of us stayed positive. And surprisingly, people tweeted more positive words during the quarantine period, compared to negative words.
By using the “NRC” lexicon, we can also label the words into eight types of emotions plus positive and negative terms.

After assigning the labels, we can group the sentiments and generate a word frequency chart like the one below. Also note that some of the terms like music, and money can be found under multiple emotion labels.
A few insights based on the emotion labeling above:
Visualization of word relationships is important when doing text mining. By arranging the words into a ‘network’ graph, we can see how words are connected with one another within a dataset.
First, we need to tokenize the dataset into bigrams (two-word). Then, we can arrange the words into a combination of connected nodes for visualization.
Some interesting insights from the network graph:
Quarantine or social distancing can be emotionally challenging, and I wanted to find out more about how people feel during this period.
Word correlation allows us to look into how common a pair of words appear together within a dataset. It gives us more insights into a particular word and its association with other words.
From the word cloud, we know that “stress” and “bored” frequently appeared in our dataset. So, I extracted three words out: “bored,” “stress,” “stuck” to look at its word correlation.
Insights from word correlation of “bored,” “stress,” and “stuck”:
To understand what people are doing at home to pass their time during this stay at home and quarantine period, I extracted three words, “play,” “read,” and “watch” to gain more insights.
Insights from word correlation of “play,” “read,” and “watch”:
Three words frequently occurred in the emotion labeling chart, which is “birthday,” “community,” and “money.” So, I looked into the word’s correlation with other terms.
Insights from the word correlation of “birthday,” “community,” and “money”:
We are able to gain insights into how people feel and what they have been doing during this Coronavirus closedown period while still following the social distancing rule.
